metadata.case_name: Appellants/Petitioners v. State of Punjab and Patiala State Bank
metadata.case_number: Civil Appeals Nos. 210 and 211 of 1961; Writ Petitions Nos. 92 and 128 of 1959

facts.text: Appellants are a joint Hindu family firm carrying on business since 1911 in grains, dal, cereals, cotton ginning and pressing, oil manufacture at Lehragaga in former State of Patiala.
Firm had Cash Credit Account in Patiala State Bank, Lehragaga branch, borrowing on pledge of stocks.
In 1951-52, heavy slump in prices caused advances by Bank to exceed market prices of goods by Rs. 2,32,000/- for appellants' firm.
On May 23, 1953, Bank sanctioned Demand Loan Account of Rs. 4,50,000/-; firm deposited title deeds, executed promissory note and memorandum.

In 1951, firm Yogiraj Neelkumar started at Lehragaga with partners Bhagirathlal (senior member of appellants' family) and strangers Kishore Chand, Banwarilal; had Cash Credit Account, owed Rs. 2,17,957-12-6 on May 23, 1953 due to slump.
Under May 23, 1953 arrangement, Rs. 4,50,000/- loan adjusted towards shortfalls of both appellants' firm and Yogiraj Neelkumar.
Appellants dispute liability for Yogiraj Neelkumar's debt of Rs. 2,17,957-12-6 as separate concern of Bhagirathlal.
Bank took steps under Patiala Recovery of State Dues Act to recover amounts.
On Feb 17, 1955, Bank issued notice under Rule 3(2) for Rs. 5,17,863-3-4; appellants replied Mar 26, 1955 requesting instalments due to slump, postponement till land acquisition compensation.
Nov 21, 1955, fresh notice for Rs. 5,24,593-10-10; appellants replied Dec 7, 1955 and Jan 6, 1956 requesting consideration and suspension.
Jan 27, 1956, Managing Director issued certificate under s.6 for Rs. 4,98,589-1-6 to Deputy Commissioner.
Appellants filed Writ Petition No. 133/1957 in Punjab High Court on Feb 16, 1957 challenging Act and proceedings.
Jul 7, 1956, notice for Rs. 25,548-4-6 on cash credit; appellants denied liability; Oct 4, 1956 ex parte determination Rs. 25,478-15/-; Dec 6, 1956 notice under Rule 7(1); certificate issued.
May 17, 1958, Writ Petition No. 389/1958 challenging Oct 4, 1956 determination.
Punjab High Court dismissed both writs Mar 6, 1959, granted certificate under Art. 133.
Petition No. 92/1959 under Art.32 challenging Act and proceedings.

Petition No. 128/1959: Petitioner merchant at Jaitu (former Nabha), Steel Rolling Mills, mortgage Rs.52,000/- Feb 20, 1951; Nov 1953 proceedings under Act; prior writ withdrawn after settlement Feb 3, 1956; default led to fresh proceedings.
May 5, 1948 Covenant by Rulers of Faridkot, Jind, Kapurthala, Malerkotla, Nabha, Patiala, Kalsia, Nalagarh for PEPSU; effective Aug 20, 1948.
Art. VI Covenant: Rights/authority/jurisdiction of Rulers vest in Union.
Aug 20, 1948 Ordinance No.1 of 2005 BK by Raj Pramukh applying Patiala laws to PEPSU.
Feb 15, 1949 Ordinance No.16 of 2005 BK extending laws.
Apr 9, 1949 Supplementary Covenant amending Art.X omitting 6-month limit.
Nov 1, 1956 PEPSU merged into Punjab under States Reorganisation Act, 1956.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Patiala Recovery of State Dues Act had ceased to be in force on material dates due to expiry of Ordinances under original Covenant.
Whether the Act and rules are repugnant to Articles 14 and 19(1)(f) and (g) of the Constitution.
Whether certificate under s.6 issued not in accordance with rules (lacking countersignature).
Whether Art.363 bars jurisdiction over disputes arising from Covenant.

petitioner_arguments.text: Act ceased to be in force as Supplementary Covenant invalid; Rulers lost sovereignty under original Covenant Art.VI; Ordinances lapsed after 6 months.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Covenant Arts. VI, X; International Law on merger

petitioner_arguments.text: Act violates Art.14: discriminates Patiala State Bank vs. other banks; special procedure for determination/recovery; post-reorganisation, applies only in former PEPSU areas.
Act violates Art.19(1)(f)(g): ousts civil courts, Managing Director as judge in own cause, no fair hearing, appeal idle, conclusive certificate, recovery as land revenue.
Certificates defective, not countersigned by Minister/Secretary.
No liability for Yogiraj Neelkumar debt.

respondent_arguments.text: Supplementary Covenant valid; Rulers retained competence; political question barred by Art.363.
Patiala State Bank distinct class (State funds); reasonable classification under Art.14; historical reasons for territorial application post-reorganisation.
No violation Art.19(1)(f)(g); contractual; procedure reasonable, follows natural justice; hierarchy of officers ensures fairness.
Countersignature not required for Managing Director per Forms.

court_reasoning.text: Supplementary Covenant invalid; complete divestiture of sovereignty to Union on Aug 20, 1948 under Art.VI; no residue in Rulers; Art.363 bars but Act applies proprio vigore in Patiala territory.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Rulers lost all sovereign powers; Ordinances extended Patiala laws but lapsed irrelevant for appellants in Patiala area.

court_reasoning.text: No Art.14 violation; State Bank separate class (public funds); rational nexus to recovery as revenue; territorial difference historical, valid classification.
court_reasoning.key_observation: State Bank differs from private banks; post-reorg historical basis upheld.

court_reasoning.text: No Art.19(1)(f)(g) violation; procedure reasonable, natural justice complied (notices replied but no dispute liability, only time sought); Managing Director impartial; appeals effective.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Rules flexible for evidence; appellants remained ex parte, admitted liability implicitly.

court_reasoning.text: Certificate valid; no countersignature needed for Managing Director per proviso and Forms.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Forms direct striking out countersignature for MD.

holdings.text: Patiala Recovery of State Dues Act and proceedings valid; not repugnant to Arts.14,19(1)(f)(g).
Supplementary Covenant ineffective but Act continues in former Patiala areas.

precedents_cited.case_name: Promod Chandra Deb v. State of Orissa
precedents_cited.relevance: Loss of sovereignty may be gradual process.

precedents_cited.case_name: Virendra Singh v. State of Uttar Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Observations on retained sovereignty in interim not applicable.

precedents_cited.case_name: Prithi Singh v. State of Pepsu
precedents_cited.relevance: Held Rulers retained powers under Covenant; disagreed.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bholanath J. Thaker v. State of Saurashtra
precedents_cited.relevance: Art.363 not bar if right independent of Covenant.

precedents_cited.case_name: Chiranjit Lal Chowdhry v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Single entity valid class under Art.14.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ram Krishna Dalmia v. Shri Justice S.R. Tendolkar
precedents_cited.relevance: Single individual class if special circumstances.
State as banker separate class for recovery.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Madhya Pradesh v. G.C. Mandawar
precedents_cited.relevance: Art.14 applies to laws of same authority.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Madhya Pradesh v. Gwalior Sugar Co. Ltd.
Bhaiyalal Shukla v. State of Madhya Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Post-reorg different laws in areas valid on historical basis.

precedents_cited.case_name: Malik Ram v. State of Rajasthan
precedents_cited.relevance: Discretion to allow evidence under similar provision.

statutes_cited.name: Patiala Recovery of State Dues Act, 2002 BK
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines state dues including Bank debts; procedure for determination, certificate conclusive, recovery as land revenue; jurisdiction bar.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Equality, right to property/business; fundamental rights enforcement; bar on Covenant disputes.

statutes_cited.name: States Reorganisation Act, 1956
statutes_cited.relevance: Merged PEPSU into Punjab; continued existing laws.

outcome.summary: Majority (Venkatarama Aiyar J. for court) dismissed appeals and writ petitions upholding validity of Patiala Recovery of State Dues Act and proceedings; Subba Rao J. dissented striking down under Art.14. Costs with one hearing fee.

key_quotes.text: "The entirety of the rights, authority and jurisdiction of the Rulers is to vest in the Union, and is to be exercisable only as provided in the Covenant."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: On complete divestiture under Covenant Art.VI

key_quotes.text: "A State Bank differs from Banks established by private agencies... it forms a category in itself."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "The creditor is made the judge of his cause and is empowered to determine the dues and realize them from the debtor."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Subba Rao J. dissent on Art.14 violation
